item.title: Mark Guzdial:Computing Education Research Blog:Dijkstra’s Truths about Computing Education Aren’t: The many kinds of programming
item.description:
• See my previous related posts which are basically Mark Guzdial again :-) :

    • Computing Education Research Blog: Proposal #3 to Change CS Education to Reduce Inequity: Call a truce on academic misconduct cases for programming assignments and it is not necessary to have to struggle to learn

    • Computing Education Research Blog:Task-specific programming languages: People aren’t dumb. Programming is hard.

  • Dijkstra’s Truths about Computing Education Aren’t The many kinds of programming: <– “Of course, there are innate differences between people, but that fact doesn’t have to limit who can program. Computers are the most flexible medium that humans have ever created. To argue that only a small percentage of people can “groove with programming” or that learning a specific programming language “mentally mutilates” is to define programming in a very narrow way. There are lots of activities that are programming” <– AMEN!

item.title: Charlie Schick:@molecularist The miracle of mundane
item.description:
• See my previous related post: Over 40 In Vancouver: Life during the Pandemic #2 Mundanity For @sillygwailo Artichokes in Burnaby @bigheadtaco ?
  • Charlie Schick:@molecularist The miracle of mundane <– “There is no magic to connect to the mundane. Just be and do.”

item.title: Google finally killed Google Play Music and miraculously YouTube Music is finally usable
item.description:
• See my previous post: YouTube Music has issues that Google Play Music didn’t: can’t reliably play downloaded playlists, etc
  • It’s hard to believe that this transition was so full of glitches but hey “under resourced team at one of the world’s wealthiest and biggest companies” is my guess :-)

item.title: Stowe Boyd: Paradoxes of Engagement: Less Communication Is More
item.description:
• I discovered this Nov 28, 2020 and updated my checkvist Blog This! Outline but haven’t blogged it until now :-) :
    • Nov 28, 2020. Stowe Boyd: Paradoxes of Engagement: Less Communication Is More via Stowe’s tweet which links to Dropbox’s Virtual First Toolkit <– “Minimizing hours for synchronous communication makes us more productive” <— I say: YES amount of synch comms minimum varies by role and by project AND AMEN :-) !

item.title: Clown by clartaq: An outlining app with notes for each headline. Written in Clojure and ClojureScript.
item.description:
• I discovered this Dec 1, 2020 and updated my checkvist Blog This! Outline but haven’t blogged it until now :-) :
    • Dec 1, 2020. clown Clown is an outliner with notes. It is written in Clojure and ClojureScript. <—– hmmmmaybe i’ll finally learn Clojure through this ?!?! Nah :-)

item.title: Stewart and the slack team: congrats on the Saleforce acquisition
item.description:
Tweets about slack’s acquisition by Salesforce

  • remember in the 2000s when a few folks including myself, yourself and

    @bmann used to go for tacos at that Vancouver restaurant run by a fab Brazilian ? Neither do I :-) Congrats

    @stewart and the entire slack team! #

  • when i got laid off by Mozilla in August, I joked to @dethe

    that i would email @stewart

    a kr*zy job application w/no resume attached: “Hey Stewart: It’s Roland. I need a job. Hire me :-) Maraming Salamat Po …Roland” Perhaps I should have :-) ROFL. JK! happy w/where I landed. #

just for fun links: about slack

  • See 2019: Kevin Kwok: The Arc of Collaboration/Slack as Else Statement
  • See 2016: Slack is the ultimate stream tool but you need HowTos to go beyond 1980s chat and it’s not a garden

Just for fun: links about flickr

  • See 2018:SmugMug Buys Flickr and pledges to continue with flickr’s fab API, yay!
  • See 2017: By April 30, 2018, the flickr API will be broken — my bet with cog dog <– LOST THAT BET :-)
  • See 2016: My 175K flickr photos are now CC0 aka public domain
  • See 2011: Still don’t have real time geotagged photo web in 2011! Proof: lack of geotagged Vancouver photos on flickr after Vancouver Canucks beat the San Jose Sharks
  • See 2011: N8 video & flickr not working - symptomatic of both Flickr & Nokia irrelevance?
  • See 2010: HD size with Street Chrome Version of 2010 Men’s Gold Medal Hockey Day Geotagged Pics from Flickr
  • See 2008: Eye-Fi’s Wireless Memory Cards for Digital Cameras Come to Canada. Best way to get your family photos to flickr!
  • See 2008: Flickr adds video - interesting that most of my videos are family videos
  • See 2008: As long as Microsoft doesn’t neuter flickr, I am fine with them buying Yahoo
  • See 2007: ShoZu + Nokia N Series phone + flickr + WiFi = least painful way to get photos online today
  • See 2007: YouTube is NOT the flickr of video <— HAHA in retrospect!
  • See 2006: N93 Review Part 1 - Nokia Web Browser works with flickr!
  • See 2005: No Flickr of video emerges - Roland’s 2006 Predictions Part 5 <—- hmmmm youtube :-) ?!?
  • See 2005: Idiom of the day “flickr of…”
  • See 2005: Deploy every 30 minutes: One secret behind Flickr time development
  • See 2005: Beware of bogus ‘long tail and ‘Just Like Flickr’ pitches
  • See 2005: Flickr leaving do at the Alibi Room tonight
  • See 2005: To get a ‘Flickr for maps’ we first need a ‘digital camera for location.’ i.e. the iPhone :-)
  • See 2005: Goodbye Flickr team! - We miss you back in Vancouver
  • See 2005: Flickr is more social than blogging - it’s a social photo blog
  • See 2005: I love my Flickr friends
  • See 2005: Flickr is 1 year old, congrats!
  • See 2004: Flickr is a social photo blogging service invented from the outside in
  • See 2004: Flickr has proven that Rich Desktop UniPlatform Web Apps are obsolete for photo sharing
  • See 2004: If Flickr can support 10MB of photos/month for free accounts, why can’t MSN Spaces?
  • See 2004: Flickr please allow me to pay you more to store more photos when I upload more than a gigabyte a month
  • See 2004: Flickr Pro - I signed up for 2 years
  • See 2004: Stewart Butterfield’s F*cking talk on Flickr Design
  • See 2004: Stewart to discuss Flickr lessons learned on Thu March 27th at 6p.m. at VFS
  • See 2004: Nice URLs on Flickr are free

item.title: Learn how microaggressions are exhausting by playing Killing Me Softly
item.description: • Discovered on Nov 25, 2020 (added it on Nov 25 to my checkvist Blog This! Outline): Killing Me Softly via Tara Robertson who wrote: “Fobazi Ettarh’s text based game is a clever and creative way for people to see how microaggressions impact people who are different from them. I found it powerful to see the options that were crossed out and no longer available for me due to accumulated physical, mental and emotional stress”

item.title: YouTube Music has issues that Google Play Music didn't: can't reliably play downloaded playlists, etc
item.description:
• i tried to switch from google play music to youtube music but oddly :-) it doesn’t reliably play my downloaded 1077 song playlist unlike google play music on my iPhone SE 2020 using the latest iOS 14.x #weAllMakeShttySoftware
  • “Every pixel isn’t sacred (TM)” :-) so I won’t complain about the different UX just for the sake of complaining :-) If I think of something substantial to complain about I’ll tweet and blog it.

item.title: Tim Ottinger: 7 code Virtues Explained
item.description:
• I discovered this Sep 25, 2020 and updated my checkvist Blog This! Outline but haven’t blogged it until now :-) :
    • Sep 25, 2020. 7 Code Virtues Explained <— good code smells :-) :
      • Working
      • Unique
      • Simple
      • Clear
      • Easy
      • Developed
      • Brief

item.title: Spanish Empire 'legibility': Filipinos were instructed by the decree of November 21, 1849 to take on permanent Hispanic surnames
item.description:
• Please refer to: Eugene Wei: Seeing Like an Algorithm: legibility and the TikTok For You Page for additional context
  • I discovered this Sep 21, 2020 and updated my checkvist Blog This! Outline but haven’t blogged it until now :-) :
    • “Nowhere is this better illustrated than in the Philippines under the Spanish. Filipinos were instructed by the decree of November 21, 1849 to take on permanent Hispanic surnames.” <— from Book Review: Seeing Like A State which Eugene Wei linked to in Seeing Like an Algorithm
